item.title: Zero-Copy and the transferTo() Method in Java
item.description: Understanding Zero-Copy and the transferTo() Method in Java One technique that helps optimize data transfer is called “zero-copy.

item.title: Introduction to REST API
item.description: Introduction to REST API REST (Representational State Transfer) is an architectural style for building web services.

item.title: Applicative and Other Functional Concepts
item.description: Applicative Functors Applicative functors, or simply applicatives, are a powerful concept in functional programming.

item.title: Back-Pressure and Error Handling in Reactor
item.description: Back-Pressure Back-pressure is a mechanism in reactive systems that allows the consumer of data to signal to the producer that it is unable to handle the current rate of data production.

item.title: Building RESTful APIs with WebFlux
item.description: Introduction to Spring WebFlux Spring WebFlux is part of the Spring Framework and provides support for reactive programming in web applications.

item.title: Currying in Java: Transforming Functions for Flexibility and Reusability
item.description: Introduction In functional programming, currying is a technique that transforms a function with multiple arguments into a sequence of functions, each taking a single argument.

item.title: Functional programming in Java: Functional Interfaces
item.description: Introduction With Java 8, Oracle introduced functional programming in the language, this is achieved by using Functional Interfaces.
